title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include details on the public debt, Federal revenue levels, and future debt projections. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on projections of the debt, historical Federal revenue levels, future debt drivers, meeting debt obligations if the limit is raised, and reduction measures if the limit is not raised. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on projections of the debt, historical Federal revenue levels, future debt drivers, meeting debt obligations if the limit is raised, and reduction measures if the limit is not raised. The report should also include proposals from the President to reduce the public debt in the short, medium, and long term, as well as the impact of an increased debt limit on future Government spending and the position of the United States dollar as the international reserve currency. The President's plan for disclosing reduction measures to avoid defaulting on government obligations when the debt limit is reached includes reporting on the total dollar amount of each measure being used. The plan for disclosing reduction measures to avoid defaulting on government obligations includes reporting the total dollar amount of measures being used, the estimated amount still available, the exhaustion date of measures, extraordinary funding measures, their duration, administrative costs, and the Administration's technological capability to pay only principal. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide public access to information by placing a link on the Department of the Treasury's homepage to a webpage serving as a repository of information. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide public access to information by placing a link on the Department of the Treasury's homepage to a webpage serving as a repository of information, including debt reports, detailed explanations, progress reports, and other relevant information related to the statutory debt limit and Government debt. Reduction measures defined in this section include directing debt issuance by the Federal Financing Bank, suspending investments in various funds, and selling assets before maturity. Other measures may be taken as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary may take additional measures as deemed appropriate, including actions related to the Disability Fund or the Postal Service Retiree Health Benefits Fund before maturity. A clerical amendment is made to the table of analysis for chapter 31 of title 31, United States Code. The House of Representatives passed a report before reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016.
